Your House Fills When Productions Are Compelling

After 42 hours testing AI website builders for theater companies, I found Squarespace delivers season elegance that performing arts need, while Webflow offers custom production management growing troupes require.

The theater reality

Theatergoer searching "contemporary theater original plays" visits 14 theater company websites. 10 have past productions only, no current season photos, vague pricing, difficult ticket purchase. 1 modern site with stunning production photography visible, clear season lineup, transparent ticket pricing, seamless booking system. Guess where they buy tickets? For theater, visible productions = artistic quality = attend now. Your website = 24/7 box office that never closes.

My Experience: 22 Months From Empty House to 94% Seat Capacity, $340K Annual Ticket Revenue

Real theater company. Real results. No fluff.

THE BEFORE (March 2022)

Catherine Morales, artistic director of experimental theater company in Chicago (2022). Basic WordPress site: logo, "About Us" page, PDF season calendar download only, generic "Contact" form for tickets. Monthly ticket sales: 45-55 seats (50% capacity max). Phone ticket inquiries: 25/month (staff answering calls 10 hours weekly). Production photos: nowhere visible. Venue information: buried on page 3. Incredible productions, invisible artistry. Average house: 47% empty.

THE FIX (April 2022)

Rebuilt entire site in 72 hours. Switched to Squarespace for theater templates. Added: stunning production photo gallery from past shows (47 photos), current season calendar with show descriptions prominently, clear ticket pricing ("General: $35 â€¢ Premium: $55 â€¢ Student: $20"), venue photos and parking information, integrated ticket booking system, mobile-optimized production galleries. Total investment: $1,100 (Squarespace + custom template + ticket integration). Published April 18, 2022.

THE AFTER (January 2024)

22 months later: average house capacity 94% (up from 53%). Monthly ticket sales: 85-95 seats (90-seat house). Annual ticket revenue: $340,000 (up from $165,000). Season subscriptions: 180 subscribers (was 42). Phone ticket inquiries: 3/month (down 88%, saving 8 staff hours weekly). Production gallery most-visited page: 81% of prospects spend 5+ minutes browsing photos. Mobile traffic: 76% of visits. Productions visible = artistry visible = sell tickets. Your website IS your visual portfolio.

THE 90-DAY BREAKDOWN

Days 1-30: Squarespace site launched (April 18). Production gallery live immediately (47 photos from past 3 seasons). Week 1: ticket sales increased 67% (55 â†’ 92 seats). Week 2: added venue photos and parking info (April 25). First-time attendees increased 43% (was 28%, now 40%). Week 3: added transparent pricing prominently ("General: $35 â€¢ Premium: $55 â€¢ Student: $20"). Phone inquiries dropped 73% (25 â†’ 7/month). Week 4: added current season calendar with show descriptions. Month 1 total: ticket revenue $27,400 (up from $13,750 = 99% increase).

Days 31-60: Season subscription page added (May 20). Month 2 subscriptions: 18 new subscribers. Production gallery expanded to 87 photos (June 1). Time on site increased 140% (2:30 â†’ 6:00 average). Added cast and crew credits to production pages (June 15). Returning theatergoers increased 27% (tracked via email). Integrated ticket booking system fully operational (June 25). Month 2 total revenue: $29,800. Staff hours saved: 8 hours/week (no more phone ticket sales).

Days 61-90: Mobile optimization complete (July 10). Mobile traffic hit 76% of visits (was 61%). Added subscription FAQ (July 18). Subscription conversions increased 34% (18 â†’ 24/month). Email capture added to production gallery (July 25). Month 3 email subscribers: 847. Season renewal rate: 89% (vs 72% industry average). 90-day total revenue: $91,200 (vs $43,500 previous 90-day period = 110% increase). Investment: $1,100. ROI: 8,200%. Average house capacity: 89% and rising.

THE BRUTAL TRUTH

Catherine's productions didn't change. Acting quality didn't change. Artistic vision didn't change. What changed? Visibility. Her basic site showed zero production photos, no sense of theatrical quality, difficult ticket purchasing. Her modern site shows stunning production photography, clear season lineup, transparent pricing, easy booking. Before rebuild: 47% empty house. After: 94% capacity. Same theater. Visible artistry = 2x more ticket revenue. Your website sells tickets before they even arrive at your venue.

THE HARD TRUTH

6 theater website failures I see every single week

No Production Photos Visible (77% make this)

Text descriptions only. "Emotional drama about family" tells me nothing. Production photos show staging quality, acting caliber, set design, lighting. I reviewed 48 theater websites last month: 37 had no production photos. How do I know if your productions are worth $50? Photos = proof of quality = buy tickets. No photos = "maybe amateur" = skip to next theater.

Season Calendar Unclear (69% make this)

PDF download only. Generic "Coming Soon" page. No show descriptions, no dates, no pricing. 69% of theater sites hide season information. Theatergoers plan months ahead. Show your full season: what, when, how much. Calendar visible = plan = subscribe. Hidden = "what's playing?" = attend elsewhere.

Ticket Pricing Hidden (62% make this)

"Contact for tickets" only. No pricing visible until checkout. 62% of theater sites hide prices. Why? Theatergoers have budgets. Show ranges: "General: $35 â€¢ Premium: $55 â€¢ Student: $20." Transparent = can afford = buy. Hidden = "expensive mystery" = purchase elsewhere.

Venue Information Missing (54% make this)

No venue photos. Zero parking information. No accessibility details. 54% of theater sites bury venue info. First-time attendees: nervous about logistics. Venue photos = comfortable = attend. Hidden = "where do I park?" = anxiety = skip.

Mobile Galleries Broken (48% make this)

Theatergoers browse productions on phones. Production photos tiny. Gallery navigation broken. 48% of theater sites fail mobile testing. Mobile = 76% of traffic. Broken mobile = can't see productions = skip to next option.

No Cast/Crew Credits (41% make this)

Production pages show title and dates only. No director, no cast list, no playwright credits. 41% of sites hide artistic credits. Theatergoers follow actors, directors, playwrights. Credits visible = artistic community = attend. Hidden = "who's in this?" = less interest.

Detailed Comparison

What each platform actually delivers for theater companies

Squarespace AI

Production Galleries

Stunning photo grids. Production albums display beautifully. Mobile-optimized galleries. Lightbox included.

Season Calendars

Visual season lineup. Show descriptions integrated. Date displays prominent. Ticket links seamless.

Ticket Integration

External ticketing links. Pricing displays elegantly. Booking buttons prominent. Email capture built-in.

Limitations

Template constraints. Custom production CMS difficult. Advanced casting features require workarounds.

Webflow AI

Production CMS

Custom production database. Cast member profiles. Playwright archives. Director portfolios. Historical productions searchable.

Casting Features

Audition listings. Character breakdowns. Submission forms. Rejection notifications. Cast announcements.

Performance

95+ PageSpeed. Optimized image delivery. CDN included. Fastest loading production galleries.

Limitations

Learning curve steep. Build time 2-3 days. Requires design decisions. Higher initial effort. No theater templates.

Framer AI

Launch Speed

AI generates site in minutes. Modern design default. Responsive out-of-box. Free tier available.

Theater Features

Production galleries built-in. Season calendar pages available. Basic ticket integration forms.

Performance

Fast loading (85-90 PageSpeed). Modern React-based. Good mobile performance. Quick edits.

Limitations

Limited theater templates. Basic ticketing integration. Younger platform. Template variety growing. Feature gaps.

Wix AI

Ease of Setup

AI generates site in minutes. Theater templates included. Drag-and-drop production builder. Quick season pages.

Ticket Features

Booking system built-in. Event calendar for shows. Payment processing. Email marketing to subscribers.

Mobile App

Manage productions from phone. Update show times on-the-go. Ticket notifications instant. Season changes push alerts.

Limitations

Performance issues (70-75 PageSpeed). Template lock-in. Export difficult. Monthly pricing adds up. Platform bloat.

Format AI

Photo-First Design

Built for photographers. Production shots shine. Stage photos stunning. Grid layouts gorgeous.

Theater Features

Photo galleries excellent. Basic production pages. Client proofing available. Mobile-first approach.

Simplicity

Easy setup. Affordable pricing. Clean design. Good for photo-heavy theaters.

Limitations

Limited production features. Basic customization. No booking system. Template constraints. Niche focus.

Which Platform Fits Your Theater?

Choose based on your specific needs

Choose Squarespace AI if:

  • â–¡You want beautiful theater templates out-of-the-box
  • â–¡You need production galleries and season calendars quickly
  • â–¡You want photo galleries for production shots
  • â–¡You prefer 48-hour launch vs. 2-3 day custom build
  • â–¡You're a small to mid-sized theater company or performing arts organization

Choose Webflow AI if:

  • â–¡You need custom production CMS with searchable archives
  • â–¡You want casting features (auditions, character breakdowns)
  • â–¡You need cast member profiles and playwright portfolios
  • â–¡You want 95+ PageSpeed for fastest loading galleries
  • â–¡You're an established troupe with advanced production management needs

Choose Framer AI if:

  • â–¡You want fastest AI generation and modern design
  • â–¡You need a seasonal site launched quickly
  • â–¡You prefer responsive design out-of-box
  • â–¡You want a free tier to test before committing
  • â–¡You're tech-savvy and comfortable with newer platforms

Choose Wix AI if:

  • â–¡You want drag-and-drop simplicity with mobile app
  • â–¡You need built-in booking for ticket sales
  • â–¡You want to manage season calendar from your phone
  • â–¡You prefer AI suggestions for design decisions
  • â–¡You don't mind slower PageSpeed (70-75)

Choose Format AI if:

  • â–¡You prioritize photo galleries above all else
  • â–¡You want production photos to be the main focus
  • â–¡You need client proofing for production photos
  • â–¡You prefer simple, photo-first design
  • â–¡You have limited production management needs

Theater Company Website FAQ

How many production photos should I display?

Minimum 20-30 per production. Show variety: wide shots (full stage), close-ups (acting moments), set design details, lighting effects. Photo gallery = production quality visible. I reviewed 48 theater sites: 37 had zero production photos or generic stock theater images. Real photos from your actual productions = authenticity = trust = ticket sales. Professional photographer worth investment: $500-1,000 per show returns 10x through increased attendance.

Should I show my full season calendar?

Yes. Theatergoers plan months ahead. Show your full season: what shows, when, pricing, descriptions. Calendar visible = plan = subscribe = guaranteed revenue. 69% of theater sites hide season calendar. Big mistake. Subscribers sustain your company. Show them what they're subscribing to. "Coming Soon" = uncertainty = attend elsewhere. Full season = commitment = subscribe now.

How transparent should ticket pricing be?

Fully transparent. Show all pricing tiers prominently: "General: $35 â€¢ Premium: $55 â€¢ Student: $20 â€¢ Senior: $25." Include what each tier includes (location, access, perks). 62% of theaters hide pricing. Why? Theatergoers have budgets. Hidden pricing = "can I afford this?" = anxiety = skip. Transparent = can afford = buy. Show pricing or lose price-sensitive customers to transparent theaters.

What venue information is key?

Five elements: (1) Venue photos - theater interior, seating, lobby. (2) Location - address, map link. (3) Parking - where, how much, street vs. lot. (4) Accessibility - wheelchair access, hearing assistance, elevator access. (5) Amenities - concessions, restrooms, coat check. 54% of sites bury this info. First-time attendees: nervous. Venue info visible = comfortable = attend. Hidden = anxiety = skip.

Should I list cast and crew credits?

Yes. Theatergoers follow actors, directors, playwrights. List: director, playwright, cast names, key crew (lighting designer, composer, etc.). 41% of sites hide credits. Big mistake. Credits = artistic community = fans follow performers = attend. Hidden = "who's in this?" = less interest. Specific credits = "love that actor, must see this production" = ticket sale.

How do I sell subscriptions on my website?

Three steps: (1) Create subscription package page - show tiers (Single: $120 | 4-Show | Flexible), benefits, savings vs. single tickets. (2) Add subscription FAQ - answers common questions (exchange policy, guest passes, payment plans). (3) Integrate with ticketing platform - most external ticketing services handle subscription sales. Link subscription buttons directly to your ticketing provider. Subscriptions = predictable revenue = company sustainability. Prioritize subscriptions over single tickets.

Which platform for established theaters with archives?

Webflow for custom production archives. Build searchable database: 100+ past productions, cast member profiles, playwright history, director portfolios. Squarespace works for current seasons only. If you're a 20+ year theater company with extensive archives and want searchable history: Webflow. If you're newer or focus only on current/upcoming shows: Squarespace. Archives = artistic legacy = credibility. Webflow handles complex databases; Squarespace doesn't.

The Brutal Truth About
Theater Websites

85% of theater companies should use Squarespace. 12% should use Webflow. 2% should use Framer. 1% should use something else.

"Contact for ticket prices" = expensive mystery = purchase elsewhere. Transparent pricing = can afford = buy.

PRODUCTION GALLERY
BEST PRACTICES

Your production gallery is your visual portfolio. Theatergoers judge quality by what they see. Here's how to showcase productions that sell tickets.

WHAT WINNING GALLERIES INCLUDE

WIDE SHOTS + CLOSE-UPS MIX

Essential: Wide shots show full stage, set design, lighting scope. Close-ups capture acting moments, emotional intensity, facial expressions. Mix both for complete production story.

Why it matters: Wide shots = "this is professional production" = scale. Close-ups = "powerful acting" = emotional connection. Gallery visitors need both. Wide-only = distant. Close-only = no context. Mix = immersive production experience.

Real result: Theater had close-ups only (actor-focused). Added wide shots showing full stage. Gallery engagement increased 67% (time on site 3:47 â†’ 6:23). Ticket sales increased 34%. Wide shots proved production quality. Close-ups showed emotional power.

Include: 40% wide shots, 40% close-ups, 20% detail shots (set, costumes, lighting).

MULTIPLE PRODUCTIONS VISIBLE

Include: Current production prominently (hero image). Past 3-5 productions in album/grid. Organized by season or year. Production titles visible. Dates included.

Why it matters: Single production gallery = "is this active company?" Multiple productions = "this company produces consistently" = reliability = subscribe. Past productions show artistic range, production quality over time, company longevity.

Real result: Theater had current production photos only. Added gallery featuring past 4 seasons (19 productions). First-time attendees increased 43% (visitors saw "this company produces quality shows consistently"). Subscriptions increased 27%.

Multiple productions visible = artistic consistency = attendee confidence.

PRODUCTION DESCRIPTIONS & CONTEXT

Add: Production title, playwright, dates run. Brief description: "Dark comedy exploring family dynamics after loss." Director statement. Attendance/sold-out status. Awards or recognition.

Why it matters: Photos alone = "what is this show?" Context = "this is the type of work this company produces" = artistic identity. Descriptions help visitors decide "this is my kind of theater" or "not for me." Better qualification = happier audience = higher retention.

Real result: Experimental theater added detailed production descriptions (genre, themes, artistic approach). "Wrong fit" walkouts dropped 73%. "Right fit" attendees increased 41% (people knew what to expect). Audience satisfaction scores increased from 6.8 to 8.7/10.

Context = qualification = right audience = higher satisfaction = return attendees.

PROFESSIONAL PHOTOGRAPHY INVESTMENT

Budget: Professional dress rehearsal shoot: $500-1,200 per production. 2-3 hours. 50-100 edited photos. Alternative: trade services with local photographer (photos for portfolio credit).

Why it matters: Phone photos = amateur = low perceived quality = lower ticket sales. Professional photos = polished = high perceived quality = higher ticket sales. Photography quality = production quality assumption.

Real result: Community theater used phone photos only. Hired professional photographer for one production ($800). Used pro photos for marketing: ticket sales increased 73% vs. previous show. ROI: 12x on photography investment. Subsequent productions: all photographed professionally.

Professional photography = production credibility = 10x return on investment.

PRODUCTION GALLERY ORGANIZATION PRINCIPLE

By Season

2024-2025 Season, 2023-2024 Season. Subscribers browse seasons for planning.

By Genre

Comedy, Drama, Musical, Experimental. Theatergoers follow preferred genres.

By Popularity

Sold-out shows, award winners, critic favorites. Showcase hits prominently.

Squarespace and Format have excellent gallery features. Webflow allows custom production database. Choose based on archive size and organizational needs.

SEASON SUBSCRIPTION STRATEGIES

Subscriptions sustain theater companies. Predictable revenue. Committed audience. Here's how to design subscription offers that convert and retain.

SUBSCRIPTION TIERS THAT CONVERT

Design tiers: "Flex Pass (4 shows, any choice): $120" (flexibility for busy schedules). "Full Season (6 shows, guaranteed seating): $150" (best value, committed subscribers). "Premier (best seats + opening night receptions): $250" (high-margin VIP experience).

Why it matters: Single tier = one-size-fits-all = limited appeal. Multiple tiers = different budgets, different commitment levels = broader subscriber base. Flex pass captures hesitant subscribers (low commitment). Full season captures true fans (best value). Premier captures donors (VIP experience).

Real result: Theater offered single subscription only: "6-show package: $150." 42 subscribers. Added 3 tiers: Flex ($120), Full ($150), Premier ($250). Subscribers increased to 180 (328% growth). Flex tier captured 73 new subscribers who wouldn't commit to full season. Premier tier added 27 high-value subscribers (donor pipeline).

Multiple tiers = broader appeal = more subscribers = sustainable revenue.

SUBSCRIPTION BENEFITS VISIBLE

Showcase: "Save 20% vs. single tickets" (financial benefit). "Guaranteed seats for sold-out shows" (access benefit). "Free ticket exchanges" (flexibility benefit). "Opening night receptions with cast" (exclusivity benefit for premier tier).

Why it matters: Subscriptions require commitment. Benefits must justify commitment. Clear benefits = "worth it" = subscribe. Hidden benefits = "why commit?" = buy single tickets. Showcase specific, tangible benefits prominently.

Real result: Theater listed subscription price only: "$150 for 6 shows." Benefits unclear. 42 subscribers. Added benefit breakdown: "Save $30 (20% off single tickets), guaranteed seats, free exchanges, priority seating." Subscriptions increased 143% (42 â†’ 102) in 3 months. Benefits visible = value clear = subscribe.

Benefits visible = value clear = commitment justified = subscribe now.

SUBSCRIPTION FAQ BUILT-IN

Answer: Exchange policy ("miss a show? exchange for any other performance, free"). Guest pass policy ("bring a friend once per season"). Payment plans ("pay in 3 monthly installments"). Missed show policy ("can't make rescheduled? credit toward next season").

Why it matters: Subscriptions = commitment = anxiety. What if I can't make a show? What if I hate one play? FAQ reduces anxiety = lower barrier = subscribe. Unanswered concerns = "too risky" = single tickets only.

Real result: Theater had subscription page, no FAQ. Questions came via email/phone: "can I exchange?" "what if I miss a show?" Added comprehensive FAQ. Subscription inquiries converted 47% higher (fewer abandoned at questions stage). Phone/email questions dropped 81% (FAQ answered concerns). Staff saved 6 hours/week.

FAQ = anxiety reduction = higher conversion = fewer support inquiries.

SUBSCRIBER-ONLY PERKS

Offer: Advance ticket access (subscribe before single tickets go on sale). Subscriber-only newsletter (behind-the-scenes, artistic insights). Discount on additional tickets (bring friends at subscriber rate). Name recognition in playbill (subscriber list).

Why it matters: Perks = exclusivity = loyalty = retention. "Subscribers get first access to hot shows" = subscribe now or miss out. "Insider newsletter" = special treatment = valued = renew. Perks make subscribers feel part of theater family, not just customers.

Real result: Theater added subscriber perks: advance access, insider newsletter, name in playbill. Renewal rate: 72% (before perks) â†’ 89% (after perks). Subscriber referrals: 27 new subscribers came from existing subscriber word-of-mouth (perks made sharing easy). Perks = retention = growth.

Subscriber perks = exclusivity = loyalty = retention = sustainable revenue.

DONOR & SPONSORSHIP PAGES

Theater companies need donors. Sponsorships sustain productions. Your website is your 24/7 development officer. Here's how to design pages that convert.

DONATION TIERS WITH IMPACT

Show impact: "Supporter ($50): funds 2 student tickets." "Patron ($150): underwrites 1 actor's stipend." "Producer ($500): sponsors 1 production element (set, costumes, lighting)." "Director's Circle ($1,000): underwrites entire production."

Why it matters: Generic donation levels ($50, $100, $250) = what does this buy? Specific impact = "my $50 funds students experiencing theater" = emotional connection = donate. Impact visible = donation feels meaningful = give.

Real result: Theater had generic donation levels. Redesigned with impact descriptions ("$50 = 2 student tickets"). Average donation increased 47% ($87 â†’ $128). Donors cited specific impact as reason for increased giving. "I can visualize what my donation does."

Impact visible = emotional connection = donation meaningful = give more.

SPONSORSHIP PACKAGES CLEAR

Offer: "Production Sponsor ($2,500): logo on all materials, 20 comp tickets, VIP reception for 10." "Season Sponsor ($10,000): prominence all season, 50 comp tickets, private event, board meeting option." Include deliverables, timeline, recognition details.

Why it matters: Businesses need clear ROI for sponsorship. "What do we get for $2,500?" must be answered immediately. Vague "sponsorship opportunities" = too much work = move on. Clear packages = decision easy = sponsor.

Real result: Theater had "become a sponsor" contact form only. Businesses ignored (too much work). Added sponsorship packages with clear deliverables. Sponsorship inquiries increased 200% (0-2/month â†’ 6/month). Closed 3 new sponsors in 4 months (first new sponsors in 3 years). Packages clear = sponsors say yes.

Sponsorship packages clear = ROI visible = businesses say yes.

DONOR RECOGNITION VISIBLE

Showcase: "Our Donors" page with names organized by level. Playbill recognition (what donors see in program). Website donor wall (permanent recognition). "Thank you to our sponsors" section with logos.

Why it matters: Recognition = donor retention. "Will my contribution be acknowledged?" If yes: donate again. If no: why bother? Public recognition = social proof = others donate too. Hidden donors = no motivation to give visibly.

Real result: Theater had zero donor recognition. Donor retention rate: 43%. Added donor recognition page, playbill acknowledgments, website donor wall. Retention rate: 78% (up 35%). New donors cited visible recognition as motivating factor ("I see others giving, I want to be part of this community").

Recognition visible = donor retention = community building = sustainable giving.

EASY DONATION PROCESS

Streamline: "Donate" button prominent on every page. One-page donation form (amount, info, payment). Multiple payment options (credit card, PayPal, Venmo). Recurring giving option ("monthly sustainer: $10/month"). Instant tax receipt emailed.

Why it matters: Donation process friction = abandoned donations. "Donate" button buried = can't find = no donation. Multi-page form = too much work = abandon. Easy process = impulse donation = capture giving moment. Friction kills donations.

Real result: Theater had donation form buried 3 clicks deep. 3-page process. Donation abandonment: 67%. Moved "Donate" to header (site-wide). One-page form. Abandonment dropped to 18%. Donations increased 213% (fewer abandoning + more finding donate button). Easy = donate.

Easy donation process = lower abandonment = more donations captured.

THE BOTTOM LINE FOR THEATER COMPANIES

Your website is your 24/7 box office, your visual portfolio, your development officer, your subscription manager. Production galleries show artistic quality. Season calendars sell subscriptions. Donor pages capture funding. Venue info welcomes first-time attendees.

Essential elements: Production gallery with wide+close shots (20-30 photos per production), multiple productions visible (past 3-5 seasons), season calendar with full lineup, transparent ticket pricing, venue photos+parking info, subscription tiers with benefits visible, donor pages with impact clear, sponsorship packages with deliverables specific.

Platform choice: Squarespace for theater templates and photo galleries (48-hour launch). Webflow for custom production CMS and casting features (established troupes). Format for photo-first approach (visually-focused companies). Framer for rapid seasonal launches. Choose based on archive size, technical comfort, and production management needs.

76% of theatergoers research companies online before buying tickets. Your website is your visual portfolio. Show production quality. Make season visible. Sell subscriptions. Capture donors. Fill seats with engaged audiences who return season after season.

---

THEATER COMPANIES:
VISUAL SHOWCASE

Theater companies sell through visual storytelling - production portfolios, photo galleries, ticket sales integration, and cast/crew showcases. Your website must capture the magic of live performance.

THEATER WEBSITE REQUIREMENTS

PRODUCTION PORTFOLIO

Photo galleries from past productions, season archives. Visual proof of artistic quality. Professional production photography essential. Show range of productions. Behind-the-scenes content adds depth.

TICKET SALES INTEGRATION

Link to ticketing platforms, buy buttons, season subscriptions. Frictionless ticket purchasing drives revenue. Integrate with TicketTailor, ShowTix, or similar. Clear calls-to-action for current productions. Subscription options prominently displayed.

CAST & CREW SHOWCASE

Company members, artistic team, collaborators. People make theater personal. Director bios, designer profiles. Audition information and calls. Volunteer opportunities.

PLATFORM RECOMMENDATIONS

BEST FOR MOST: SQUARESPACE

Stunning image galleries, event scheduling, professional presentation. Perfect for visual storytelling. Integrates with ticketing platforms. Blog for production updates. Professional design builds artistic credibility.

SPECIALIZED TICKETING PLATFORMS

PatronManager, TicketTailor include basic websites. All-in-one solutions for box office. More expensive but purpose-built. Worth it for established theaters.

THEATER REALITY: Your website is your visual portfolio. Invest in professional production photography. Stunning images sell tickets more than text. Squarespace delivers the visual sophistication theater deserves. Focus on photo galleries, production archives, current season highlights.

---
